text: in 2001 I had been selected by CIA's
Counterterrorism Center to lead the
jawbreaker team which was the primary
team that would lead the invasion of
Afghanistan after the attacks of 9/11 I
had been given instructions to
accomplish a series of things number one
was destroyed the Taliban because they
wouldn't surrender bin Laden number two
was to destroy al Qaeda as an
organization and then of course finally
eliminate bin Laden we would initially
land and position ourselves in the
Panjshir coordinate with the Northern
Alliance from there and of course very
rapidly we were able to seize the city
of Kabul but we realized that bin Laden
had fled south to the White Mountains
he'd moved along the road in a massive
group there about 750,000 people with
him it was clear to me that the
military's instructions were slightly
different than mine I could see that
they were very rapidly getting
themselves involved in we have to hold
the ground you have to stabilize the
country and they were not as focused on
the mission of finding and eliminating
bin Laden I had gone to the US military
I had requested a team to accompany me
they didn't want to do that yet when I
realized that I wasn't going to get
support for that I decided to go alone I
was able to assemble a team of
individuals coordinate with the Afghans
I had you know four CIA officers three
current JSOC Joint Special Operations
Command individuals and one SF medic and
those eight men would be led by two
sixteen-year-old Afghans out of the
eight men four volunteered to go up into
the mountains to find bin Laden's
position get up over the top of al Qaeda
and then contact me they contacted me
said we have these guys on the ground
request permission to commence attacks
then of course that yep let's begin
remember Grim Reaper this is range one
over so this is for Americans alone in
the mountains with ten Afghans against
750 to a thousand people on the ground
then they lined up all the aircraft in
the region brought them all in we would
drop a blue 82 which is a 15,000 pound
device so we actually threw one of those
at him we threw a lot of other b-52s at
him once we got that battle not 56 hours
I was able to go to Army Special Forces
and then only later would 40 guys from
Delta Force up here so you know at no
point were there more than 60 Americans
there there were more journalists at
that battle than Americans I did not
inform CIA headquarters that I was doing
this because I was very concerned that
they wouldn't authorize any of it there
would have been a slew of questions I
didn't want any questions I didn't want
to hear anything from anybody and quite
frankly I didn't trust the seventh floor
of the CIA to do the right thing because
they had not done the right thing for a
number of years and I didn't care if I
was fired - relieved either I was just
going to do it you know when people say
it was a failure it doesn't bother me in
the least I think that they don't
understand the circumstances of the
battle was of course a flawed
masterpiece all I could do was it was
manage the forces I had to destroy as
many members of al-qaeda as possible
bin Laden limped out of there his force
was destroyed it took years to rebuild
it for I think for almost all of the
individuals that were on that deployment
it was a life defining mission and
effort
you
